Description: Terracotta figure fragment of woman's head. Large head fragment. Wearing high stephane (broken) with rosettes and rosette earings. Mould-made and solid, stephane was added later. White coating, traces of red paint on hair and black on stephane. Fine red-brown fabric with dark grey core and abundant mica. Head only, the face is chipped and much perished.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Hellenion (Naukratis), Site 9 (Hogarth), 2 feet above basal mud
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Fine red-brown micaceous fabric resembles that of East Greek terracottas found in Naukratis. Marked with Gutch number '32', but also x29 and '129' or '139'. Gutch dates this to c. 450BC and the Fitzwilliam provide a late 5th century BC date (in Hogarth 1899, p. 81, no. 32, 'found with no. 25, on pl.10, and no. 33 a copy of this one).
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 81, no. 32)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.340) (Phase 3)
